citation.article-title: Mycoplasma hyopharyngis, a new species from swine.

p.s: Description of Mycoplasma hyophaiyngis sp. nov.
Mycoplasma hyophaiyngis (hyo-pha-ryn'-gis. Gr. n. hys, hyos a swine, Gr. n. pharynx, phaiyngis throat; M . L. gen. n. hyopharyngis of a hog's throat)
Electron microscopic examination of thin sections revealed pleomorphic cells surrounded by a triple-layered membrane and no cell wall.
Typical fried egg colonies are produced.
Coccoid to coccobacillus forms are produced.
Cells pass through a filter with 0.45-μm pores but most are retained on filters with 0.20-μm pores.
Cultures are resistant to penicillin and thallium acetate, and no reversion to cell wall forms occurs in the absence of these compounds.
Cultures are inhibited by digitonin and sodium polyanethol sulfonate.
The cultures do not grow on medium supplemented with 1% PPLO serum fraction or cholesterol but do grow well in horse serum-containing medium.
Arginine is utilized, but glucose and urea are not.
Cultures produce phosphatase but do not hydrolyze esculin or gelatin and do not digest casein.
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride is not reduced aerobically.
Cultures produce lysis of sheep erythrocytes and do not hemadsorb swine or guinea pig erythrocytes.
The species is serologically distinct from other Mycoplasma species.
Cultures were isolated from the pharyngeal and nasal cavities of pigs.
The G+C content of the DNA is 24 mol%.
The type strain is H3-6B F (ATCC 35707).
